sub_title: Historian of the Future and PhD Candidate
summary:
Science is an idea, a framework for creating knowledge, a social utility, a worldview, and an active element of human society and culture. It is energizing and enlightening but by no means infallible. In all that complexity, there is certainly a lot to explore. Furthermore, the need for knowledgeable science communicators is at an all time high, and I desire to fill that niche. 

I seek to apply my historical understanding of the history of science into debates on science, technology, and society that draw parallels to our present predicaments. Wish me luck or join the ride, because I'm definitely out to do some good.

treasury_media.description: Co-hosts Paul Carr and Daniela De Paulis welcome space historian David Skogerboe to talk about the pro-space activism of Arthur C. Clarke.

treasury_media.description: The feature article I wrote for the 4th quarter 2019 NASA News & Notes Newsletter celebrating the often ignored Apollo 12 mission during its 50th anniversary.

treasury_media.title: The Godfather of Satellites: Arthur C. Clarke and the Battle for Narrative Space in the Popular Culture of Spaceflight, 1945-1995.
treasury_media.description: Master's thesis submitted for the History and Philosophy of Science program at Utrecht University.

contributors.headline: Historian of the Future and PhD Candidate

courses.name: Science and the Dilemmas of Modernity

profile_positions.description:
The SATFUTURE project aims to understand the history, and future, of satellite infrastructures, focusing on satellite futures, or visions of desirable satellite infrastructures that set expectations for the future and are used to shape the direction of technological and societal development. Focused at the intersection of history of science, technology, and science & technology studies, SATFUTURE employs concepts of sociotechnical imaginaries and visioneering to showcase how the communication of the future shapes the way technologies are developed and utilized. It asks: How have expectations shaped the development of past satellite infrastructures? In what ways were these expectations incorporated into the final product? And how have these expectations changed over time?

SATFUTURE will contribute to understanding Europe’s history in space by looking back to two of the European Space Agency’s first satellite infrastructures: Meteosat, for meteorology, and the European Remote Sensing Satellite (ERS), for Earth observation. These two case studies offer a unique opportunity to reflect on where Europe’s expectations of space infrastructures once were, and where they stand today. 

SATFUTURE aims to analyze how expectations, packaged in satellite futures, shaped Europe’s first satellite infrastructures. Examining these satellite futures provides a powerful means of understanding the forces that shaped our satellite infrastructures to this point, and how we are transcribing our expectations of the future onto the technologies of today.
profile_positions.title: PhD Candidate in History of Satellite Futures

profile_positions.description:
Update: I completed the program and graduated on June 30th, 2020!

I jumped on the once in a lifetime opportunity to drop everything, move to the Netherlands, and study my favorite historical subject matter. With nearly a decade of professional work experience under my belt following my undergrad, I'm grateful to now have the opportunity to focus all of my mental energy toward making the most of my graduate school education. I've approached my study of the history and philosophy of science very practically, always striving to find histories with stories relevant to modern challenges. 

Additionally, I have taken multiple courses in science communication, investigative journalism, and STS (Science, Techology, Society), as a historical and modern understanding of science will best prepare me to speak to scientific practice with greater authority. I'm still on this journey, but there is ample room for more knowledge in the old noggin'.
profile_positions.title: Graduate Student MSc History and Philosophy of Science

company.name: NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration

profile_positions.company: NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration
profile_positions.description:
During Fall 2019, I acted as the NASA History Division Student Intern at NASA HQ in Washington DC. The NASA History Division, part of the larger Office of Communication, is composed of historians and archivists stationed at each of the NASA facilities that work to preserve, study, publish and share NASA’s history.

My main task was daily management of the @NASAHistory social media accounts, researching and creating content for Flickr (17K followers), Twitter (887K), and Facebook (2.3M).
· https://twitter.com/NASAHistory
· https://www.facebook.com/NASAHistoryOffice/
· https://www.flickr.com/photos/nasacommons/

I strove to provide the necessary context and relevance to make the posts more valuable than just pretty pictures (which sometimes were a-ok). This took time to learn, and by the end of the internship, engagement metrics showed I was trending in the right direction. 

The Apollo 12 50th anniversary (Nov. 14th-24th) took place during my tenure, and I led the charge in curating #Apollo12 content, including a featured article in NASA's quarterly newsletter titled “Apollo 12: Why Don’t You Know Me? You Should.” (Attached below)

Overall, I developed firsthand experience in the collaborative realm of professional public communication, from assisting NASA’s Office of Legislative Affairs with promotional events on the Hill to participating in the production of professional history books. I engaged in production meetings, manuscript reviews, and image selection, seeing how these books were made, start to finish. This meant I read a lot, and I developed a foundation of space history knowledge beyond the main highlights.

Upon the internship's conclusion in mid-December, I returned to Utrecht to complete writing my thesis, using material I gathered throughout my time contributing to NASA History.
profile_positions.title: Intern, NASA History Division

profile_positions.description:
Building upon my experience at Seattle Central College, I transitioned to South Seattle College within the Seattle Colleges District to support the Professional/Technical trade programs. In this role, I wear many hats, but the primary objective is to ensure our students land the job they trained for and advocate to make South Seattle College the premiere destination for industry employers to find candidates. 

Specifically, I support the following programs and industry sectors:

•	Aviation Maintenance 
•	Aerospace Composites
•	Landscape Horticulture
•	Automotive Technology
•	Auto Body Collision 
•	Diesel & Heavy Machinery
•	Computing Technology - IT Systems Specialist and Network Administration
•	Business IT & Accounting

For the 500+ students and alumni of these programs, I act as their main point of contact for career discernment, internship placement, career readiness, and job placement. I support students in creating career plans and connecting them to industry recruiters and specific employers. Each student comes with different backgrounds, barriers, skill sets, and end goals and I approach each meeting with their specific needs in mind.

For the many employers who seek qualified candidates, I act as the liaison between their company and our school, obtaining student referrals to meet recruiting needs, scheduling information sessions, and organizing hiring events.

To ensure a flow of opportunities, I develop and maintain partnerships with employers through Technical Advisory Committee (TAC) meetings to determine hiring needs, create recruiting pipelines, discuss equitable labor practices, and support diversity workplace initiatives.

In addition, I am ‘Embedded’ within our programs, working alongside faculty to teach sector specific career readiness workshops that implement employer feedback to meet industry trends and demands.
profile_positions.title: Embedded Career Specialist - WorkSource

profile_positions.description:
The Career Services Center at Seattle Central College is a wonderful free resource for students and the local community, and I had the pleasure of being its manager and collaboratively finding ways to improve and expand services, all while working directly with individuals seeking professional guidance. 

On any given day, I would meet with 3-6 students or job-seekers, and provide career counseling utilizing Holland Codes, MBTI, and Dependable Strengths assessments; assist job search efforts, crafting resumes, cover letters, conducting mock-interviews; and teach workshops on a range of subjects related to academic and career success.

Empty blocks on my calendar meant I finally had time to tackle the other half of my job. I managed the annual budget, produced marketing materials to increase awareness of our services to the student body and local community, and developed partnerships with employers in the Puget Sound region to create recruitment pipelines for freshly graduated students.

During my tenure, I proudly assisted hundreds of people, and the staff within the center assisted hundreds more; I collaborated with department leads, and expanded the center's services through the funding of an additional staff member; and played a consistent role in the implementation of the community college Guided Pathways initiative. I was happy to stay within the Seattle Colleges District in my next role, which greatly utilizes the knowledge I gained at the Career Services Center.
profile_positions.title: Program Support Supervisor - Career Services Center

profile_positions.description:
There's no denying I was intimidated when I was selected to manage the Student Records Department of a major university, overseeing the records and transcripts of over 20,000 students and alumni. The learning curve was sharp, but I found my bearings quickly through the support of a great work environment. The value of a positive and collaborative team is immense!

I supervised 13 professional staff and student employees who assisted in incoming transcript evaluations, course equivalencies, grade changes, document imaging, and outgoing transcript orders. I had to ensure all of this happened in accordance with Federal, State, and University regulations, but it didn't stop there! I had to become the Subject Matter Expert for FERPA Laws, accreditation standards, transfer guidelines, the OnBase ECM Imaging software, and a variety of specific forms on Ellucian's Banner software.

By the time I left, I had done all of the above, along with acting as the project manager for the initial   implementation of e-transcripts, streamlining processes between advising and records, and participating in hiring committees that interviewed and selected over 10 new employees. I genuinely enjoyed my time at UCO.

I also took a Documentary Film making course on my lunch breaks that sparked my hobby in video production. Go Bronchos!
profile_positions.title: Coordinator of Student Records

profile_positions.description: I worked in an extremely busy AT&T retail store, assisting dozens of customers everyday. I am exceptionally skilled in customer facing positions, and was a consistent top performer in my store for sales and customer satisfaction metrics, sometimes sneaking into the state and national rankings. I became known for my ability to calm escalations and developed a loyal base of clients that would seek me out specifically.
profile_positions.title: Retail Sales Consultant

profile_positions.description:
For two years, I taught English to large classrooms of Taiwanese children ages 3-17. I was awarded HESS Teacher of the Year in 2011 and selected as a lead chaperone for a prestigious English camp in Singapore, where I was responsible for 18 students on their first trip abroad. I believe my decision to take the risk and move abroad by myself in early 2010 was the best decision I've ever made. 

After a few uncomfortable months, and a great deal of research and repetition, I turned out to be an effective and fun teacher. I learned a great deal about managing classrooms, specifically with children, and the art of calmly improvising when everything goes south, which was the norm. I come back to these strategies all the time.
profile_positions.title: English Teacher

profile_positions.title: Testing Assistant

profile_positions.description:
This was my first job, working as a Propagation Assistant in a wholesale greenhouse operation. Turns out it was interesting work, and I kept coming back, joining the propagation team every summer for 10 more seasons, 2000-2009 and again following my return from Taiwan in 2012.

Every year, I assisted in growing over 300,000 propagules of nearly 400 different species via softwood cuttings, seedlings, and grafting, while acting as additional support in maintaining the greenhouses through weeding, pest management, soil creation, and irrigation repairs. 

I take pride in knowing I helped bring millions of new organisms into the world, and I learned a valuable skill in the process!
profile_positions.title: Plant Propagator
